SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Class SQLInsert

java.lang.Object
org.klojang.jdbc.SQLStatement<SQLInsert>
org.klojang.jdbc.SQLInsert
All Implemented Interfaces:
AutoCloseable
public final class SQLInsert extends SQLStatement<SQLInsert>
Facilitates the execution of SQL INSERT statements. SQLInsert instances can be obtained either via SQLSession.prepareInsert() or via an InsertBuilder.
See Also:
  • SQLSession.prepareInsert()
  • SQL.insert()

  • Method Details

    • bind

      public SQLInsert bind(Object bean)
      Binds the values in the specified JavaBean to the named parameters within the SQL statement. Bean properties that do not correspond to named parameters will tacitly be ignored. The effect of passing anything other than a proper JavaBean (e.g. an Integer, a String, or an array) is undefined.
      Overrides:
      bind in class SQLStatement<SQLInsert>
      Parameters:
      bean - the bean whose values to bind to the named parameters within the SQL statement
      Returns:
      this SQLInsert instance

    • bind

      public SQLInsert bind(Record record)
      Binds the values in the specified record to the named parameters within the SQL statement. Record components that do not correspond to named parameters will tacitly be ignored.
      Overrides:
      bind in class SQLStatement<SQLInsert>
      Parameters:
      record - the record whose values to bind to the named parameters within the SQL statement
      Returns:
      this SQLInsert instance

    • bind

      public SQLInsert bind(Object bean, String idProperty)

      Binds the values in the specified JavaBean to the parameters within the SQL statement. Bean properties that do not correspond to named parameters will tacitly be ignored. The effect of passing anything other than a proper JavaBean (e.g. an Integer, String or array) is undefined. The idProperty argument must be the name of the property corresponding to the primary key column. The database-generated key for that column will be bound back into the bean. Therefore, make sure the bean is modifiable. Notably, do not pass a record type.

      Klojang JDBC does not support table definitions that generate keys for multiple columns.

      Parameters:
      bean - the bean whose values to bind to the named parameters within the SQL statement
      idProperty - the name of the property representing the auto-generated primary key.
      Returns:
      this SQLInsert instance

    • bind

      public SQLInsert bind(Map<String,Object> map)
      Binds the values in the specified map to the named parameters within the SQL statement. Map keys that do not correspond to named parameters will tacitly be ignored.
      Overrides:
      bind in class SQLStatement<SQLInsert>
      Parameters:
      map - the map whose values to bind to the named parameters within the SQL statement
      Returns:
      this SQLInsert instance

    • bind

      public SQLInsert bind(Map<String,?> map, String idKey)
      Binds the values in the specified map to the named parameters within the SQL statement. Keys that do not correspond to named parameters will be ignored. The idKey argument must be the name of the map key corresponding to the primary key column. The database-generated key for that column will be bound back into the map. Therefore, make sure the map is modifiable.

      Klojang JDBC does not support table definitions that generate keys for multiple columns.

      Parameters:
      map - the map whose values to bind to the named parameters within the SQL statement
      idKey - the name of the map key representing the auto-generated primary key.
      Returns:
      this SQLInsert instance

    • execute

      public long execute()
      Executes the INSERT statement. If the SQLInsert was configured to retrieve auto-generated keys, this method returns the auto-generated key, else it returns -1.
      Returns:
      the key generated by the database or -1 if retrieval of auto-generated keys was suppressed.

    • executeAndSetID

      public long executeAndSetID()
      Executes the INSERT statement. Any JavaBean that was bound using bind(bean, idProperty will have its ID property set to the key generated by the database. JavaBeans that were bound using bind(bean) will remain unmodified. The same applies mutatis mutandis for Map objects. An IllegalStateException will be thrown if the SQLInsert was configured to suppress the retrieval of auto-generated keys.
      Returns:
      the key generated by the database

    • insertBatch

      public <U> void insertBatch(List<U> beans)
      Saves the specified JavaBeans to the database. This method combines the binding and execution phase. Therefore it must be called on a "fresh" instance. That is, it must not contain any bound values yet. This will be the case if the instance has just been created, or you have just executed the INSERT statement (which resets the instance), or you have explicitly called SQLStatement.reset().

      For large batches consider using the SQLBatchInsert class as it is likely to be more performant.

      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the beans or records
      Parameters:
      beans - the beans or records to save

    • insertBatchAndGetIDs

      public <U> long[] insertBatchAndGetIDs(List<U> beans)
      Saves the specified JavaBeans to the database and returns the keys generated by the database. This method combines the binding and execution phase. Therefore it must be called on a "fresh" instance. That is, it must not contain any bound values yet. This will be the case if the instance has just been created, or if you just executed the INSERT statement (which resets the instance), or if you just called SQLStatement.reset().

      For large batches consider using SQLSession.setValues() or the SQLBatchInsert class as they are likely to perform better.

      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the beans or records
      Parameters:
      beans - the beans or records to save
      Returns:
      the keys generated by the database

    • insertBatchAndSetIDs

      public <U> void insertBatchAndSetIDs(String idProperty, List<U> beans)
      Saves the specified JavaBeans to the database and sets the specified ID property in each of them to the key generated by the database. This method combines the binding and execution phase. Therefore it must be called on a "fresh" instance. That is, it must not contain any bound values, beans or maps yet — which would be the case if the instance has just been created, or you have just executed the INSERT statement (which resets the instance), or you have explicitly called SQLStatement.reset().
      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the beans or records
      Parameters:
      idProperty - the name of the property corresponding to the primary key
      beans - the beans or records to save
